tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: A song. A psalm of Asaph
tn.text: "This is a psalm that Asaph wrote"
"and do nothing to help us"

tn.ref: Look, your enemies are making a commotion
tn.text: Here "making a commotion" means they are rioting and rebelling. AT: "Look, your enemies are rebelling against you"

tn.ref: those who hate you have raised their heads
tn.text: The phrase "raised their heads" is way of saying they are rebelling against God. AT: "those who hate you are defying you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"those whom you protect." This refers to the Israelites.

tn.ref: the name of Israel will no longer be remembered
tn.text: Here "name" represents a reputation or the memory of someone. This can be stated in active form. AT: "no one will ever remember the Israelites existed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: They have schemed together with one strategy
tn.text: "Your enemies have agreed together with one plan"

tn.ref: against you they have made an alliance
tn.text: "they have joined together against you"
The writer continues to list the people groups who want to destroy Israel.
This refers to the people of Edom who lived in tents. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is the name of a people group that lived on the east side of the Jordan River. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These all represent the people of each area or tribe. AT: "the people of Gebal, the Ammonites, the Amalekites ... the Philistines" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is the name of a region south of the Dead Sea. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This represents the people of Assyria. AT: "the people of Assyria" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This refers to the people of the nations of Moab and Ammon. You can make clear the understood information. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

This may be a musical term that tells people how to sing or play their instruments here. Some translations write the Hebrew word, and some translations do not include it. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:003:001|3:2]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_transliterate]])

tn.ref: Do to them ... for the earth
tn.text: The writer is asking God to defeat Israel's enemies as he has done in the past. (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "Midian" represents the people of Midian. AT: "did to the Midianites" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
These are names of men. Jabin was king of Hazor. Sisera was the commander of Jabin's army. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a river in northern Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a town in northern Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: became like manure for the earth
tn.text: This means the bodies of Sisera and Jabin were not buried but were left to rot. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
The writer continues to remind God of other enemies he has defeated for Israel in the past. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
These are all names of kings. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Here "They" refers to Oreb, Zeeb, Zebah and Zalmunna.
This speaks about the land of Israel as if it were land for sheep to graze and God were the shepherd watching over it. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The writer uses similes to describe God's total destruction of Israel's enemies. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: make them like the whirling dust, like chaff before the wind
tn.text: Both statements speak of God destroying his enemies as if he were a strong wind easily blowing them away. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: like the fire that burns the forest, and like the flame that sets the mountains on fire
tn.text: Both statements speak of God's punishment as if it were a fire, and the enemies of God are things that burn in the fire. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: Chase them with your strong wind, and terrify them with your windstorm
tn.text: Both statements ask God to destroy the enemies with storms. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Here "faces" represents the whole person. AT: "Make them very ashamed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

Here "name" represents God's power. God's enemies acknowledging that God is powerful is spoken of as if they are seeking to find Yahweh. AT: "they might acknowledge that you are powerful" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Possible meanings are 1) God's enemies admit that God is powerful or 2) God's enemies are asking God for help or 3) God's enemies start to worship and obey him.

tn.ref: May they be put to shame and be terrified forever
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Make them ashamed and terrified forever" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"may they die while they are ashamed"
This can also be stated as the writer making a request to God. AT: "Cause them to know" (UDB)

tn.ref: are the Most High over all the earth
tn.text: God ruling over everything in the earth is spoken of as if he were elevated higher than everything else. AT: "are supreme, and you rule all things on the earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
